columns.text: In this problem, we need to identify the different factors that can affect the break-even point or value of a certain investment or project.

**a.** In order to solve this problem, we first need to determine how much extra costs are the hybrid cars and compare how much you can save on fuel throughout the lifespan of the project. 

As already stated in the problem, the additional price to acquire the hybrid car is $\$5,500$ and an additional annual cost of $\$350$

To interpret this with regards to the time of the project, we need to multiply the annual cost by $6$ years then add it to the cost of acquiring.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total additional cost}&=(\$350 \times 6\ \text{years})+\$5,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,100+\$5,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$7,600
\end{aligned}$$

This gives us an additional cost of $\$7,600$ throughout the whole $6$ years.
Now, we can solve for the average fuel consumption. We can do this by dividing the price of fuel by the estimated mileage of the car.

Taking the difference, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Diference in fuel consumption}&=\$0.095-\$0.0731\\
&=\$0.0219
\end{aligned}$$

This means that for every mile, the hybrid costs $\$0.0219$ less than the traditional sedan

Divide this by the number of years to get the annual miles:

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{347,031.96}{6}&=57,838.66
\end{aligned}$$

In order to achieve the break-even, you need to drive $57,838.66$ miles annually.

**b.** For this, we can start by multiplying the current price per gallon to the break-even miles.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$2.85 \times 57,838.66&=\$164,840.18
\end{aligned}$$

We can now divide this price by $15,000$ miles to get the break-even price per gallon.

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\$164,840.18}{15,000}&=\$10.99
\end{aligned}$$

This means that if we only drive $15,000$ miles annually, we will reach break even if the price per gallon is $\$10.99$

**c.** Since we are now given a $10\%$ rate, we need to incorporate this to our solutions. Basically, we are still calculating the break-even miles and the break-even price per gallon. This means that the net present value (NPV) is still at zero. Therefore, our solution for the break-even miles will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\text{Initial cost}+(\text{Difference in fuel consumption}\\
& \times \text{Annuity factor} \times \text{Miles})\\
\end{aligned}$$

The initial cost is basically solved by adding the the additional price to acquire and the annual additional cost multiplied to the annuity factor. Using an annuity table for $10\%$ return in $6$ years, our factor will be $4.3553$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=-(\$7,600+\$350 \times 4.3553)\\
&+(\$0.0219 \times 4.3553 \times \text{Miles})\\
\$9124.355&=0.0954 \times \text{Miles}\\
\text{Miles}&=95,643.13
\end{aligned}$$

Given the $10\%$ rate, you need to drive $95,643.13$ miles annualy to achieve break-even

Divide both sides of the equation by $0.0954$ to get the number of miles:
$$\begin{aligned}
\$9124.355&=0.0954 \times \text{Miles}\\[15 pt]
\text{Miles}&=95,643.13
\end{aligned}$$

Given the $10\%$ rate, you need to drive $95,643.13$ miles annually to achieve break-even

For the break-even price per gallon, we can use the same formula but the computation for the OCF will rely on using the $15,000$ miles value times the annuity factor and the cost per gallon

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=-(\$7,600+\$350 \times 4.3553)\\
&+(15,000\times 4.3553 \times \text{Difference per gallon})\\[15 pt]
\text{Difference per gallon}&=\$0.1397
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have the difference per gallon, we can multiply this by the price and divide the answer by the difference in price per gallon that we used in Step 8

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Break-even cost per gallon}&=\dfrac{\$0.1397 \times \$2.85}{\$0.0219}\\[15 pt]
&=\$18.18
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even cost per gallon, considering the interest rate, is $\$18.18$ per gallon

**d.** In the previous parts, we assumed that the depreciation of the car follows a straight-line format where it reaches zero value at the end of the lifespan of $6$ years. In part **c**, we were able to adjust the assumption using an interest rate and the annuity factor that takes the change in future prices into account.
